title: Discover the origins and evolution of PL/I.
description: Learn how PL/I shaped modern mainframe programming.

theory.content:
History and Evolution

PL/I (Programming Language One) was developed by IBM in the early 1960s as part of the System/360 initiative to unify programming across scientific, engineering, and business domains. Officially introduced in 1964, PL/I combined the computational power of FORTRAN with the data-handling features of COBOL.

Early compilers ran on IBM 7090 and System/360 mainframes, pioneering structured programming, recursion, and multitasking. Through the 1970s–1980s, IBM enhanced PL/I with structured constructs, advanced I/O, and strong exception handling for enterprise reliability.

Technical Features and Syntax

PL/I supports a wide range of data types including FIXED, FLOAT, COMPLEX, and bit strings. Its control structures — DO, IF, and SELECT — allowed for clear, modular programming.

Its exception handling mechanism using ON conditions influenced later languages such as Ada and C. PL/I also supported tasking and multitasking, enabling concurrent execution and efficient mainframe use.

Integration with IBM Mainframe

PL/I was designed to fully leverage IBM mainframes, particularly z/OS, MVS, and VM. It works seamlessly with VSAM for file access, IMS for transactions, and DB2 for database integration.

Using IBM’s Enterprise PL/I Compiler and Debug Tool, developers can build and maintain reliable systems interoperable with COBOL, C, and Assembler through IBM’s Language Environment (LE).

Legacy and Modern Relevance

While modern languages like C, Java, and Python dominate new development, PL/I remains integral to mainframe modernization. Many financial and government systems continue to rely on millions of lines of PL/I code.

Its design influenced future programming paradigms in exception handling, data management, and concurrency, making it a lasting cornerstone of computing history.
